''' Robert Hubert''' (c. 1640 – 27 October 1666) was a watchmaker{{cite book|last=Leasor|first=James|title=The plague and the fire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tgui1pU3ckQC&pg=PA235|year=2001|publisher=House of Stratus|isbn=0-7551-0040-9|page=235|chapter=A Scapegoat is Hanged}} from [[Rouen]], France, who was [[Wrongful execution|executed]] following his [[false confession]] of starting the [[Great Fire of London]]. ==Great Fire of London== {{main|Great Fire of London}} Between 2 and 5 September 1666, a major fire broke out in [[Pudding Lane]] in the [[City of London]], and proceeded to destroy around 80 percent of the old city. ==Confession== Hubert's confession, at first, was of starting a fire in [[Westminster]]. However, this story proved unsatisfactory, and his confession changed upon learning that the fire never reached Westminster.{{cite web |url=http://europeanhistory.about.com/od/ukandireland/a/agreatfirelon_4.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318195224/http://europeanhistory.about.com/od/ukandireland/a/agreatfirelon_4.htm |archive-date=2007-03-18 |publisher=About.com |title=The Great Fire of London 1666: Hunting For A Scapegoat |first=Robert |last=Wilde |quote=...at first he said he'd started it in Westminster, which the fire never even got near..." |df=dmy-all}} Having learned that the fire started in [[Pudding Lane]], in the house of the baker Thomas Farriner (or Farynor), he then claimed to have thrown a crude fire grenade through the open window of the Farriner bakery.{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/09/01/the_odd_body_confessing_sam/ |title=What is a Confessing Sam? |work=[[The Register]] |date=1 September 2006 |access-date=3 September 2006 |first=Stephen |last=Juan |quote=Hubert confessed to having started the fire by throwing a crude fire grenade through an open bakery window.}} He claimed to have acted with accomplices, who stopped the water cocks to sabotage the effort to put out the fire. Hubert's confessed motive was, apparently, that he was a French spy,{{cite web |url=http://www.oldlondonmaps.com/viewspages/0157.html |title=The Great Fire of London, 1666 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060705100148/http://www.oldlondonmaps.com/viewspages/0157.html |archive-date=2006-07-05 |quote=... he claimed to have had accomplices had stopped the water cocks for the water supply of London so that the fire could not be fought effectively (during the fire the reservoirs of water kept in the city for such an eventuality were strangely dry). Hubert (who claimed he was an agent for the French) ... |website=Old London Maps |publisher=Sara Douglass Enterprises |df=dmy-all}} and an agent of the Pope. ==Trial and execution== Hubert's confessions never seemed convincing. His retroactive change of story to fit the facts, though, was not the only reason. Hubert had not even been in London at the time that the fire broke out — he had not even arrived in England until two days after the fire started.Juan (2006), ''The Register''. "...Hubert, a sailor, had not arrived in England until two days after the fire started...". That he was not in the country at the time of the outbreak of fire is not in doubt, as testified, years later, by a captain of the [[Sweden|Swedish]] ship the ''Maid of Stockholm'',{{cite magazine |url=http://www.cercles.com/review/r1/hanson.html |title=Book Review: The Dreadful Judgement: The True Story of the Great Fire of London 1666 |first=Alain |last=Lauzanne |year=2001 |magazine=Cercles |issn=1292-8968 |quote=... a few years later the master of the Maid of Stockholm testified that the young man, who was bound for Rouen, was on board his ship when the fire broke out.}} that he personally had landed Hubert ashore two days after the outbreak of the fire.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E3D81331F931A1575AC0A9649C8B63 |title=When London Started Over |first=Simon |last=Winchester |date=2002-09-22 |work=[[The New York Times]] |quote=Many years later a Swedish ship's captain testified that he had landed the watchmaker ashore two days after the fire had started.}} Having never seen the Farriner bakery, Hubert also did not know that it had no windows. What is more, he was judged so severely crippled that it would have been impossible for him to throw the claimed grenade.Juan (2006), ''The Register''. "[he] was never near the bakery where the fire started, and was so badly crippled that throwing anything was beyond him. If that were not enough, the bakery had no windows." Hubert's confession is often attributed to a mental simplicity, an inability to understand what it was he was doing; a kind of "Confessing Sam" tendency. One source claims, though, that the confession was coerced "probably by an extreme form of torture".Winchester (2002), ''The New York Times''. "[he] was coerced into confessing (probably by an extreme form of torture) to having hurled a home-made chemical fireball into the bakery." As ''[[The London Gazette]]'' suggests, some put the disaster down to chance:
[...] notwithstanding which suspicion, the manner of the burning all along in a Train, and so blowen forwards in all its way by strong Winds, make us conclude the whole was an effect of an unhappy chance, or to speak better, the heavy hand of God upon us for our sins [...]''The London Gazette'', [[:File:London-gazette.gif|8 September 1666]]
Despite the many obvious flaws and impossibilities in Hubert's confession, a scapegoat was needed. Even the king, [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], was suspected of having instigated it, in order to punish the people of London for the execution of his [[Charles I of England|father]].Lauzanne (2001), ''Cercles'' Nationalism was high with Britain embroiled in the [[Second Anglo-Dutch War]], and many nationalities--the Dutch, French, Spanish, and Irish--were suspect.{{cite web |url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/learning/features_facts/tudor_stuart_london_2.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427114020/http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/learning/features_facts/tudor_stuart_london_2.html |archive-date=2006-04-27 |title=Investigate The Great Fire of London |publisher=[[Museum of London]] |access-date=2018-10-26 |df=dmy-all}} Frenchmen were particularly vulnerable, as illustrated by the murder of a Frenchman whose tennis balls were mistaken for 'balls of fire'. Hubert, a foreigner and Frenchman, was a chief suspect, as suggested by the ''London Gazette'':
[...] Strangers, Dutch and French were, during the fire, apprehended, upon suspicion that they contributed mischievously to it, who are all imprisoned, and Informations prepared to make a severe inquisition [...]
Catholics were also chief suspects, and accusations were so formal as to be added to the [[Monument to the Great Fire of London|Monument]] in 1668, which stayed (with brief interruptions) until 1830:
[...] the most dreadful Burning of this City; begun and carried on by the treachery and malice of the Popish faction.Wilde, ''About.com''. "Catholics remained the favoured villain [...] the inscription remained until 1830."}}
Hubert had convenient attributes. He was convicted and sentenced to death at the [[Old Bailey]]. Despite the contradictoriness of both Hubert's account and of public opinion, the Farriner family, in whose bakery the fire had started, was naturally under pressure — they needed to show that their ovens had been doused properly— and three members of the family were present in the jury.Wilde, ''About.com''. "...the group judging him contained three members of the Farriner family. They vehemently denied any wrongdoing and claimed to have doused the ovens properly...". Thomas Farynor stated that, after midnight, he had:
gone through every room and found no fire, but in one chimney, where the room was paved with bricks, which fire I diligently raked up in embers [...] no window or door might let wind disturb them and that it was absolutely set on fire on purpose[...]
Few of the jury at his trial actually believed Hubert guilty. One contemporary account claims that Hubert was "only accused upon his own confession; yet neither the judges nor any present at the trial did believe him guilty, but that he was a poor distracted wretch, weary of his life, and chose to part with it in this way."{{cite book |chapter-url=http://www.trivia-library.com/c/time-and-history-100-am-the-great-london-fire.htm |chapter=Time and History 1:00 A.M. The Great London Fire |first1=David |last1=Wallechinsky |first2=Irving |last2=Wallace |first3=Amy |last3=Wallace |title=The People's Almanac |volume=3 |year=1981 |author1-link=David Wallechinsky |author2-link=Irving Wallace |isbn=0688037518}} The jury stated that he did not have "the fear of God before his eyes, but [was] moved and led away by the instigation of the devil".Wallechisnky, Wallace & Wallace (1981). "The Old Bailey jury, however, found that, "not having the fear of God before his eyes, but moved and led away by the instigation of the devil," Hubert had deliberately started the fire." Hubert was hanged at [[Tyburn, London]], on 27 October 1666.{{cite web |url=http://col4.museumoflondon.org.uk/mediaLib/382/media-382948/original.pdf |title=Information on Robert Hubert |format=PDF |publisher=[[Museum of London]] |access-date=2018-10-26 |df=dmy-all}} As his body was being handed to the [[Company of Barber-Surgeons]] for dissection, it was torn apart by a crowd of Londoners.Lauzanne (2001), ''Cercles''. "The manner in which the Londoners who watched the execution of Hubert tore his body to pieces as it was about to be handed to the beadle of the Worshipful Company of Barber Surgeons for dissection bears witness to the hatred that the fire had aroused." It was hoped that with Hubert's death, "the talk of plots and conspiracies might die with him". In 1667, after the need for scapegoats had died down, the fire was officially attributed to 'the hand of God, a great wind and a very dry season...'. One source attributes the accident to a spark falling upon a bale of straw in the bakery of the Farriners,{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E3D81331F931A1575AC0A9649C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=When London Started Over | first=Simon | last=Winchester | date=22 September 2002}} and many assume the spark to have come from the oven of the Farriner's bakery.{{Cite web|url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Learning/Learningonline/features/tudor/tudor_stuart_london_2.htm|title=Investigate The Great Fire of London |publisher=Museum of London|accessdate=8 April 2009 |quote=...and everyone blames the open door of Farriner's oven."}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hubert, Robert}} [[Category:1666 deaths]] [[Category:Executed French people]] [[Category:French people executed abroad]] [[Category:People executed by Stuart England]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:People from Rouen]] [[Category:People executed by the Kingdom of England by hanging]] [[Category:People executed at Tyburn]] [[Category:Great Fire of London]] [[Category:Executed people from Normandy]] [[Category:False confessions]]

{{POV|date=February 2014}} {{Politics of Singapore}}
'''Separation of powers in Singapore''' is founded on the concept of [[constitutionalism]], which is itself primarily based upon distrust of power and thus the desirability of [[limited government]]. To achieve this, the [[Constitution of Singapore|Constitution]] of the [[Singapore|Republic of Singapore]] splits the power to govern the country between three branches of government – the legislature, which makes laws; the [[Government of Singapore|executive]], which executes them; and the [[judicial system of Singapore|judiciary]], which enforces them. Each branch, while wielding legitimate power and being protected from external influences, is subjected to a system of [[separation of powers#Checks and balances|checks and balances]] by the other branches to prevent abuse of power. This [[Westminster system|Westminster constitutional model]] was inherited from the British during Singapore's colonial years.
The Singapore system of government, as with those of a number of other [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] jurisdictions, exhibits a partial [[separation of powers]]. The [[Cabinet of Singapore|Cabinet]] is a parliamentary executive as the [[Prime Minister of Singapore|Prime Minister]] and other ministers are drawn from the [[Parliament of Singapore#Members of Parliament|Members of Parliament]] (MPs). Hence, it is the Cabinet that drives Parliament's legislative agenda. In addition, the executive possesses some law-making power as it is authorised to issue [[sources of Singapore law#Subsidiary legislation|subsidiary legislation]], while the [[President of Singapore|President]] is a member of both the executive and the legislature.
The legislature exercises a check upon the executive by imposing a weak sanction through the doctrine of [[individual ministerial responsibility]]. Cabinet ministers may be called upon to justify their policies in [[Parliament of Singapore|Parliament]] by elected MPs ([[backbencher]]s belonging to the ruling party and opposition MPs), as well as non-elected Members ([[Non-constituency Member of Parliament|Non-constituency members of parliament]] (NCMPs) and [[Nominated Member of Parliament|Nominated members of parliament]] (NMPs)).
In line with the concept of constitutional supremacy, the judiciary has the role of safeguarding the Constitution, and acts as an institutional check through its inherent power to strike down unconstitutional laws, and to invalidate acts or decisions by the executive which are inconsistent with the Constitution or with [[administrative law in Singapore|administrative law rules]]. However, judicial power is not unfettered and is also restrained by constitutional and legislative prohibitions. The judiciary also defers to the executive where [[justiciability|non-justiciable]] matters are involved. [[Judicial independence in Singapore|Judicial independence]] allows the judiciary to check the exercise of power by the other branches of government more effectively, enhancing the idea of the separation of powers. Constitutional safeguards exist to secure the independence of [[Supreme Court of Singapore|Supreme Court]] judges, but a point of contention is that [[State Courts of Singapore|State Courts]] judges do not enjoy security of tenure as they are members of the [[Singapore Legal Service]] and may be transferred out of the State Courts to other departments of the Service by the Legal Service Commission.
The separation of powers in Singapore is also enhanced by intra-branch checking mechanisms. Within the executive, the Elected President adds to the overall scheme of checks and balances through his [[powers of the President of Singapore|discretionary power]] to block certain government actions. However, the presence of an override mechanism wielded by Parliament blunts the office's powers. The [[Presidential Council for Minority Rights]] also serves as a check on the legislature by reviewing [[bill (proposed law)|bills]] to ensure that they do not discriminate against racial and religious minorities. However, the Council's powers are constrained by the presence of an override mechanism as well.
==Introduction==
===Constitutionalism=== [[File:Lord Emerich Edward Dalberg Acton.jpg|thumb|upright|[[John Dalberg-Acton, 1st Baron Acton|Lord Acton]] (1834–1902) wrote: "Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely."]]
The idea of [[separation of powers]] is founded on the basis of [[constitutionalism]]. The notion of constitutionalism is primarily one of culture. Lawrence W. Beer proposed in ''Constitutional Systems in the Late Twentieth Century Asia'' (1992) that constitutionalism is where "national history, custom, religion, social values and assumptions about government meet positive law, economic force and power politics".<ref>{{citation|author=Lawrence W. Beer|title=Constitutional Systems in the Late Twentieth Century Asia|location=Seattle, Wash.; London|publisher=[[University of Washington Press]]|year=1992|page=2|isbn=978-0-295-97174-2}}.</ref> As a result, the notion of constitutionalism differs from region to region and there can be no one specific notion of constitutionalism across the world. As [[Thio Li-ann]] puts it, "constitutionalism is itself a form of culture which is constructed, rather than 'organic'; a constitutional order is the 'most complex form of socio-political organisation'".<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|authorlink=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Province of Constitutional Law|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=[[Singapore Academy of Law|Academy Publishing]]|year=2012|pages=3–93 at 13–14|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref>
Even though the constitutional culture differs from country to country, in general the "idea of modern constitutionalism rests upon the distrust of power".<ref>{{citation|author=Carl J[oachim] Friedrich|authorlink=Carl Joachim Friedrich|title=Limited Government: A Comparison|location=Englewood Cliffs, N.J.|publisher=[[Prentice Hall]]|year=1974|pages=12–13|isbn=978-0-13-537159-6}}.</ref> This is founded on the problem of power as espoused by [[John Dalberg-Acton, 1st Baron Acton|Lord Acton]] – that "[p]ower tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely".<ref name="Acton">{{citation|author=John Emerich Edward Dalberg-Acton, First Lord Acton|authorlink=John Dalberg-Acton, 1st Baron Acton|chapter=Appendix [Letter to Bishop Mandell Creighton, 5 April 1887]|editor=John Neville Figgis|editor-link=Neville Figgis|editor2=Reginald Vere Laurence|title=Historical Essays and Studies|url=https://archive.org/details/a544621300actouoft|location=London|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan and Co., Limited]]|year=1907|pages=503–505 at 504|oclc=847945644}}.</ref>
It is this distrust of power that has resulted in the need to ensure separation of powers. The ultimate aim of constitutionalism is to establish the idea of [[limited government]]. In countries that subscribe to constitutional supremacy, the constitution is the supreme law of the land and demarcates the extent of power that each branch of government (the executive, legislature and [[judiciary]]) is able to wield, as well as how each branch may act as a checking mechanism on the other branches. This aspect of constitutionalism is "concerned with curbing oppressive government and preserving individual freedom while retaining a realm for the exercise of legitimate governmental power".<ref>{{citation|author=Timothy J. O'Neill|title=Liberal Constitutionalism & Bureaucratic Discretion|journal=Polity|date=Spring 1988|volume=20|issue=3|pages=371–393 at 371|jstor=3234868}}, cited in Thio, "The Province of Constitutional Law", p. 38, para. 01.103.</ref>
===Separation of powers=== The state needs laws in order for it to function, and this results in the creation of three distinct powers: one to create laws (the legislature), one to execute the laws (executive), and one to ensure that the rules are being followed (judiciary). Each branch of government has its own set of functions and hence the power that is available for each branch to wield is different as well. Even though this power to govern the society has already been divided into the three branches, the idea of constitutionalism implies "a commitment towards regularised legal restraints on power in the form of inter- and intra-institutional checks and balances and legal procedure".<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Constitutional Framework of Powers|editor=Kevin Y[ew] L[ee] Tan|title=The Singapore Legal System|edition=2nd|location=Singapore|publisher=[[National University of Singapore|Singapore University Press]]|year=1999|pages=67–122 at 72|isbn=978-9971-69-213-1}}.</ref>
Simply put, there must be a separation of powers, where each branch is able to wield its own power to perform its functions independent of undue influence but yet be restrained from an abuse of its power through checking mechanisms. A system of checks and balances serves to ensure that each power will not be subject to abuse by the controlling body. While the checking mechanisms exercised by each body should be sufficient to prevent abuse of power, they should also not overstep their boundaries and encroach upon the powers that the other branches wield lawfully. In ''[[Federalist No. 51|The Federalist No. 51]]'' (6 February 1788), [[James Madison]] wrote that "[a]mbition must be made to counteract ambition",<ref>{{citation|author="Publius" (James Madison)|authorlink=James Madison|chapter=On Maintaining a Just Partition of Power among the Necessary Departments|url=https://archive.org/details/federalist00hami|title=The Federalist: A Collection of Essays Alexander Hamilton, John Jay and James Madison Interpreting the Constitution of the United States as Agreed upon by the Federal Convention, September 17, 1787|edition=rev.|location=New York, N.Y.|publisher=Colonial Press|year=1901|pages=284–288 at 285|oclc=317653138}}.</ref> while in ''[[Federalist No. 48|The Federalist No. 48]]'' (1 February 1788) he explained the need for a system of checks and balances in preserving the separation of powers doctrine:<ref>"Publius" (Madison), "Constitutional Connection of the Departments of Government", ''The Federalist'', pp. 271–276 at 271.</ref>
{{quote|... unless these departments be so far connected and blended as to give to each a constitutional control over the others, the degree of separation which the maxim requires, as essential to a free government, can never in practice be duly maintained.}}
====Reasons for separation of powers==== [[File:AduC 001 Montesquieu (1689-1755).JPG|thumb|upright|An engraving of [[Montesquieu]] (1689–1755) by [[Émile Bayard]], published in ''Album du centenaire'' (1889). Montesquieu wrote in ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' (1748) that arbitrariness and tyranny would result if executive, legislative and judicial powers were united in the same person.]]
One of the most notable proponents of the conception of separation of powers was [[Montesquieu]] in ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' (1748). In that work, he observed:<ref>{{citation|author=Baron de Montesquieu (Charles de Secondat)|authorlink=Montesquieu|others=Thomas Nugent, transl.|chapter=Book XI: Of the Laws which Establish Political Liberty with Regard to the Constitution|chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/spiritlaws01montgoog|title=[[The Spirit of the Laws|The Spirit of Laws]]|edition=rev.|volume=1|location=New York, N.Y.|publisher=Colonial Press|year=1899|pages=149–182 at 151–152|oclc=1355299}}.</ref>
{{quote|When the legislative and executive powers are united in the same person, or in the same body of magistrates, there can be no liberty; because apprehensions may arise, lest the same monarch or senate should enact tyrannical laws, to execute them in a tyrannical manner.
Again, there is no liberty, if the judiciary power be not separated form the legislature and executive. Were it joined with the legislative, the life and liberty of the subject would be exposed to arbitrary control; for the judge would be then the legislator. Were it joined to the executive power, the judge might behave with violence and oppression.}}
The separation of powers brings its merits in just governance. However, where each branch wields more power than it legitimately should, there is room for abuse, leaving the rest of the society open to the potential of being ruled by tyranny of the majority. Hence it is important that a system of checks and balances is in place to ensure that power will not be abused to the detriment of the people.<ref name="Thio 160">{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=Constitutional Principles|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=155–222 at 160|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref>
Separation of powers also promotes the efficiency and competence in allocating powers by "[fitting] form to function by matching tasks to the most suitable body". Specialization of the functions and roles of the various branches helps to promote efficiency as each branch of government has specific tasks and goals that it can work towards. After all, one of the main aims of this measure is to ensure that society's goals are met, and this can be done through an efficient system of government. Lastly, separation of powers helps to enhance democratic responsibility. With the various branches of government being responsible for specific functions, people are more inclined to vote into Parliament (which will form part of the legislature) persons who will best represent their views.<ref name="Thio 160"/>
====Pure and partial separation of powers==== There are two main notions of separation of powers – pure separation of powers and partial separation of powers. Pure separation of powers was a concept formulated by M. J. C. Vile in ''Constitutionalism and the Separation of Powers'' (1967) as a constitutional arrangement where there are no overlaps at all between the branches of government. In fact, "the persons who compose these three agencies of government must be kept separate and distinct, no individual being allowed to be at the same time a member of more than one branch. In this way each of the branches will be a check to the others and no single group of people will be able to control the machinery of the State".<ref>{{citation|author=M. J. C. Vile|title=Constitutionalism and the Separation of Powers|location=London|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1967|page=13|isbn=978-0-19-827160-4}}.</ref>
In practice, this is hard to achieve and largely remains a theoretical notion. One of the few states that can be considered close to achieving this state of separation of powers would be the United States of America.<ref>Thio, "Constitutional Principles", p. 159, para. 03.015.</ref> On the other hand, legal systems that follow the [[Westminster system|Westminster model]] adopt a partial separation of powers. This occurs when there are overlaps across the three branches. In Singapore, the legislature and executive overlap because ministers in the [[Cabinet of Singapore|Cabinet]] are appointed from the [[Parliament of Singapore#Members of Parliament|Members of Parliament]] (MPs). Thus, the same group of people are able to exercise both the power to make law and to execute the law.<ref name="Art 25(1)">{{Singapore legislation|title=Constitution|ed=1985|rep=1999}}, Art. 25(1).</ref>
==Origins of the separation of powers in Singapore== The origins of the separation of powers in Singapore lie in the Westminster constitutional model inherited from the United Kingdom during its colonial past, first as part of the [[Straits Settlements]], and then as an independent nation. When Singapore was transferred to the [[Colonial Office]] in 1867, it was given a normal colonial constitution. This constitution vested legislative authority over the colony in the [[Legislative Council of the Straits Settlements]]. The constitution also retained the structure of the judicial system already established by the Second Charter of Justice, which had vested judicial power in the Court of Judicature of the Straits Settlements. In 1877, an [[Executive Council (Commonwealth countries)|Executive Council]] was introduced into the government of the Straits Settlements, with the role of advising the [[List of British Governors of the Straits Settlements|Governor]] on all affairs of importance.<ref>{{citation|author=Kevin Tan Yew Lee|title=The Evolution of Singapore's Modern Constitution: Developments from 1945 to the Present Day|url=http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/2/1989-1-SAcLJ-001-Tan.pdf|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140119163808/http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/2/1989-1-SAcLJ-001-Tan.pdf|archivedate=19 January 2014|journal=Singapore Academy of Law Journal|year=1989|volume=1|pages=1–28 at 1–4}}.</ref>
From 1877 onwards, this broad structure specifying the powers of the three organs of state remained largely intact. The constitution remained unchanged until the end of the [[Japanese occupation of Singapore|Japanese Occupation]], when the Straits Settlements were disbanded. Although constitutional amendments were then made, the overarching hierarchy of executive, legislative and judicial bodies which had been operating before the war was retained. This basic arrangement also survived Singapore's [[Singapore in Malaysia|merger]] and [[history of the Republic of Singapore#Independence of Singapore|separation]] from [[Malaysia]], and consequent independence.<ref>Tan, "The Evolution of Singapore's Modern Constitution", pp. 6 and 14.</ref>
The Singapore Constitution thus vests legislative, executive and judicial power in the legislature, executive and judiciary respectively.<ref>Constitution, Arts. 23, 38 and 93.</ref> This is a defining feature of Westminster-style constitutions, of which Singapore's constitution is one.<ref name="Mohammad Faizal">{{cite CommonLII|litigants=Mohammad Faizal bin Sabtu v. Public Prosecutor|court=SGHC|year=2013|num=163|parallelcite=[2012] 4 S.L.R. [''Singapore Law Reports''] 947 at 956–957, paras. 11–12|courtname=auto}}.</ref> The doctrine is implicit from the fact that the organs of state have separate roles.<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants=Hinds v. The Queen|court=UKPC|year=1977|num=22|parallelcite=[1977] A.C. 195|courtname=auto}}.</ref>
The separation of powers doctrine in Singapore is not absolute but qualified; it is not pure but partial.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Constitutional Framework of Powers|editor=Kevin Y[ew] L[ee] Tan|title=The Singapore Legal System|edition=2nd|location=Singapore|publisher=[[National University of Singapore|Singapore University Press]]|year=1999|pages=67–122 at 77|isbn=978-9971-69-212-4}}.</ref> The partial separation of powers doctrine in Singapore is exemplified in the following ways:
[[File:Walter Bagehot NPG cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|An 1891 [[mezzotint]] of [[Walter Bagehot]] (1826–1877). Bagehot described the [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom]] as a "committee of the legislative body selected to be the executive body".]]
*'''Members of the executive drawn from the Parliament'''. First, Singapore has a parliamentary executive. While the legislature exercises legislative power and the executive exercises executive power, these two institutions are not separate or independent. This feature was described by [[Walter Bagehot]] as "the efficient secret of the English Constitution", which was defined as "the close union, the nearly complete fusion of the executive and legislative powers". This fusion is facilitated by the existence of the Cabinet, as a "committee of the legislative body selected to be the executive body".<ref name="Bagehot">{{citation|author=Walter Bagehot|chapter=The Cabinet|chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/englishconstitu05bagegoog|title=[[The English Constitution]]|location=London|publisher=[[Chapman & Hall|Chapman and Hall]]|year=1867|pages=1–36 at 12|oclc=60724184}}.</ref> The Ministers in Cabinet are appointed from the MPs;<ref>Constitution, Art. 25(1).</ref> they thus exercise the power both to make and execute the law. *'''Executive issues subsidiary legislation'''. Second, the executive has power to issue [[sources of Singapore law#Subsidiary legislation|subsidiary legislation]] and assent to treaties. This is contrary to the [[nondelegation doctrine|non-delegation doctrine]], by which one branch of government must not authorise another entity to exercise the power or function which it is constitutionally authorised to exercise itself.<ref name="Thio 83">Thio, "The Constitutional Framework of Powers", p. 83.</ref> In Singapore, subsidiary legislation, though made by the executive, has "legislative, as opposed to administrative effect". The contravention of the non-delegation doctrine is deemed necessary because time constraints make it impossible for Parliament to enact all laws. In subsidiary legislation, the broad, general terms in [[primary legislation]] are explained and elaborated upon.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Legislature and the Electoral System|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=285–359 at 314|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref> *'''President a member of both the executive and legislature'''. Third, the [[President of Singapore|President]] is vested with both executive authority and legislative power.<ref>Constitution, Arts. 23 and 38.</ref> As a member of the legislature, in general the President must assent to all laws passed by the legislature.<ref>Constitution, Art. 58(1): "[T]he power of the Legislature to make laws shall be exercised by Bills passed by Parliament and assented to by the President."</ref> However, the President has limited [[powers of the President of Singapore|discretionary executive powers]] to withhold assent to certain [[bill (proposed law)|bills]], including attempts by the [[Government of Singapore|Government]] to draw down financial reserves accumulated by past governments, to change the investment ability of the [[Central Provident Fund Board]], and to alter the President's own discretionary powers.<ref>Constitution, Art. 21(2)(c). See generally {{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Executive, the Prime Minister and Cabinet Government|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=369–381|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref>
The English influence on Singapore's governmental system is visibly strong, though Singapore's system fundamentally differs from that of the United Kingdom as it is [[unicameralism|unicameral]]. Singapore's take on the separation of powers is greatly informed by its unique values and legal culture. The traditional separation of powers doctrine in the United Kingdom is based on a fundamental distrust of human nature, and by extension, an even greater distrust of power, which "tends to corrupt".<ref name="Acton"/> As a result, it is necessary for each branch of government to be checked and managed, to prevent its otherwise absolute and uncurtailed power being abused. Singapore, on the other hand, has based its system of government on the election of trustworthy and honourable leaders, instead of on the implementation of a system specifically to prevent dishonourable ones misusing their power. In other words, aside from legal methods of controlling government – that is, through institutionalised checks and balances – non-legal methods are used as well,<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Theory and Practice of Judicial Review of Administrative Action in Singapore: Trends and Perspectives|url=https://nus.academia.edu/LiannThio/Papers/971945/The_Theory_and_Practice_of_Judicial_Review_of_Administrative_Action_in_Singapore_Trends_and_Perspectives|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/649A00vfF?url=http://nus.academia.edu/LiannThio/Papers/971945/The_Theory_and_Practice_of_Judicial_Review_of_Administrative_Action_in_Singapore_Trends_and_Perspectives|archivedate=23 December 2011|editor=Yeo Tiong Min|editor2=Hans Tjio|editor3=Tang Hang Wu|title=SAL Conference 2011: Developments in Singapore Law between 2006 and 2010: Trends and Perspectives|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2011|pages=714–752 at 725|isbn=978-981-08-8670-7|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> "internally from Parliament and the Executive itself in upholding high standards of public administration and policy".<ref>{{citation|author=Chan Sek Keong|authorlink=Chan Sek Keong|title=Judicial Review – From Angst to Empathy: A Lecture to Singapore Management University Second Year Law Students|url=http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/516/%282010%29%2022%20SAcLJ%20469-489_Chan%20CJ.pdf|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63bXAGCt7?url=http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/516/%282010%29%2022%20SAcLJ%20469-489_Chan%20CJ.pdf|archivedate=1 December 2011|journal=Singapore Academy of Law Journal|date=September 2010|volume=22|pages=469–489 at 480, para. 29|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}.</ref>
This attitude towards the control of public power reflects the [[Confucianism|Confucian]] ideals underlying the Government's stance that separation of powers is less important than choosing leaders that can be trusted and do not need to be fettered:<ref>{{citation|title=Shared Values [Cmd. 1 of 1991]|location=Singapore|publisher=Printed for the [[Government of Singapore]] by Singapore National Printers|year=1991|at=para. 41|oclc=42436009}}.</ref>
{{quote|The concept of government by honourable men (''junzi''), who have a duty to do right for the people, and who have the trust and respect of the population, fits us better than the Western idea that a government should be given as limited powers as possible, and should always be treated with suspicion unless proven otherwise.}}
==Inter-branch checks== Since independence, Singapore's legal system has evolved increasingly towards its local context.<ref>{{citation|author=Gary F. Bell|chapter=The Singapore Legal System in Context – Whither the Concept of the National Legal System?|editor=Kevin Y[ew] L[ee] Tan|title=The Singapore Legal System|edition=2nd|location=Singapore|publisher=Singapore University Press|year=1999|pages=1–25 at 12|isbn=978-9971-69-213-1}}.</ref> Developments in government and constitutionalism have brought about distinctive features in its system of checks and balances. A few issues arise due to the long-standing one-party dominance in Singapore's political system. Since the [[Singaporean general election, 1963|1963 general election]], the [[People's Action Party]] has repeatedly prevailed as the majority party in Parliament.<ref>{{citation|title=Parliamentary Elections Results|url=http://www.eld.gov.sg/elections_past_parliamentary.html|archiveurl=http://perma.cc/8V6H-VUSC|archivedate=20 January 2014|publisher=[[Elections Department]]|date=8 October 2013}}.</ref> In the recent [[Singapore general election, 2011|2011 general election]], it managed to capture 81 of 87 seats contested.<ref>{{citation|title=2011 Parliamentary Election Results|url=http://www.eld.gov.sg/elections_results2011.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306071538/http://www.eld.gov.sg/elections_results2011.html|archivedate=6 March 2014|publisher=Elections Department|date=8 October 2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}.</ref>
===Legislative checks on the parliamentary executive=== As mentioned above, Singapore has a parliamentary executive in which Cabinet ministers are drawn from and accountable to Parliament. The existence of a parliamentary executive does not mean government by Parliament; it is a separate and distinct branch of power, suited to make policies and carry out executive decisions.<ref name="Thio 83"/>
However, because of the party system, the Cabinet is often composed of the leaders of the majority party in Parliament. As such, it asserts control over the legislative agenda.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Executive, the Prime Minister and Cabinet Government|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=369–384 at 377|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref> One associated problem is that of an "[[elective dictatorship]]" – [[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone]], once described it as the dominance of the executive over a subservient Parliament.<ref>{{citation|author=Lord Hailsham|authorlink=Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|title=Elective Dictatorship [The Richard Dimbleby lecture; 1976]|location=London|publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]|year=1976|isbn=978-0-563-17254-3}}, reviewed in {{citation|author=Basil Markesinis|authorlink=Basil Markesinis|title=Elective Dictatorship|url=http://pa.oxfordjournals.org/content/XXX/3/324.citation|journal=[[Parliamentary Affairs]]|year=1977|volume=XXX|issue=3|pages=324–327}}.</ref>
====Ministerial responsibility==== The doctrine of [[individual ministerial responsibility]] is a [[Constitution of Singapore#Constitutional conventions|constitutional convention]] adopted from the Westminster constitutional model. According to this doctrine, Parliament imposes a check on the Cabinet by scrutinising government bills and actions, and calling upon ministers to justify policies before the House in open debate. This ensures that the Cabinet is accountable not only to Parliament but also to the public, who have access to transcripts of Parliamentary debates.<ref name="Thio 85">Thio, "The Constitutional Framework of Powers", p. 85.</ref>
Consistent with the party system, the Government also observes collective ministerial responsibility or [[Cabinet collective responsibility]]. This is enshrined in Article 24(2) of the Constitution, which states that "[s]ubject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Cabinet shall have the general direction and control of the Government and shall be collectively responsible to Parliament". According to Prime Minister [[Goh Chok Tong]] in 2002, "[t]he principle of collective responsibility means that there is an agreement between the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues that they will stand together as a team when accounting for their actions before Parliament". This principle also seeks to enhance inter-ministry co-ordination by ensuring that all ministers share the same broad policy positions, and that there is no "unnecessary duplication or, worse, mutual contradiction".<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Goh Chok Tong|mplink=Goh Chok Tong|office=[[Prime Minister's Office (Singapore)|Prime Minister]]|title=Debate on President's Address|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00068266-ZZ|date=5 April 2002|volume=74|column=544–545}}.</ref>
This check on the executive branch, however, is a weak one. Since Cabinet ministers are often the leaders of the majority party in Parliament, they may enforce [[party discipline]] and loyalty through the [[Parliament of Singapore#Party whip|party whip]] such that MPs from that party conform to the [[party line (politics)|party line]]. This means that a majority of Parliament will be less inclined, if at all, to oppose or challenge the executive's decisions.<ref name="Thio 85"/>
====Efficacy of opposition MPs, NCMPs and NMPs====
=====Opposition members of parliament===== Given the one-party dominance in Singapore, the opposition MPs in Parliament play a crucial role in checking the executive. They enforce the doctrine of ministerial responsibility by providing constructive criticism of executive policies. They are also entitled to vote for or against bills and motions, but this may exercise little influence over majoritarian power. As such, the effectiveness of the opposition hinges on its ability to keep the executive, as well as the majority party, vigilant and accountable to society.<ref>Thio, "The Constitutional Framework of Powers", pp. 86–87.</ref>
=====Non-Constituency members of parliament===== [[File:Sylvia Lim at a Workers' Party general election rally, Bedok Stadium, Singapore - 20110430-02.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Sylvia Lim]] at a [[Workers' Party of Singapore|Workers' Party]] rally at [[Bedok Stadium]] during the [[Singaporean general election, 2011|2011 general election]]. Before being elected as an MP for [[Aljunied Group Representation Constituency|Aljunied GRC]] in that year, Lim was an NCMP between 2006 and 2011.]]
[[Non-constituency Member of Parliament|Non-Constituency members of parliament]] (NCMPs) were introduced into Parliament for the purpose of ensuring "the representation in Parliament of a minimum number of Members from a political party or parties not forming the Government".<ref>Constitution, Art. 39(1)(b).</ref> The number of NCMPs in Parliament is nine less the number of opposition MPs elected at a general election.<ref>The NCMP scheme is regulated by the {{Singapore legislation|title=Parliamentary Elections Act|cap=218|ed=2011}} ("PEA"), ss. 52(1).</ref>
Marking a departure from the Westminster model, the NCMP scheme was conceived to introduce alternative political voices in Parliament. According to Deputy Prime Minister [[Wong Kan Seng]], the presence of a parliamentary minority would help younger MPs gain experience in debate, ensure transparency of Parliamentary proceedings and "dispel any suspicions of cover-ups", as well as give the opposition a forum to put forth their agenda.<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Wong Kan Seng|mplink=Wong Kan Seng|office=[[Ministry of Home Affairs (Singapore)|Minister for Home Affairs]]|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment)|billurl=http://www.parliament.gov.sg/sites/default/files/100003.pdf|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00004346-WA|date=26 April 2010|volume=87|column=58}}.</ref> NCMPs enjoy the same privileges and immunities as elected Members, but they cannot vote on a bill to amend the Constitution; a supply, supplementary or final supply bill; a [[money bill]], a [[motion of no confidence|vote of no confidence]] in the Government or a motion for the removal of the President from office.<ref>Constitution, Art. 39(2).</ref>
Some commentators have remarked that the NCMP scheme is premised on the assumption that the one party-dominance will continue to govern Singapore's political state of affairs.<ref>Thio, "The Legislature and the Electoral System", p. 307, para. 06.058; {{citation|author=Tsun Hang Tey|title=Singapore's Electoral System: Government by the People?|journal=Legal Studies|date=December 2008|volume=28|issue=4|pages=610–628 at 612–616|doi=10.1111/j.1748-121X.2008.00106.x}}.</ref> Nonetheless, the scheme gives the opposition parties a platform to share their political ideas, as well as augment opposition strength in Parliament as a check on the executive.<ref>Thio, "The Legislature and the Electoral System", p. 305, para. 06.053.</ref>
=====Nominated members of parliament===== [[Nominated Member of Parliament|Nominated members of parliament]] (NMPs) are another departure from the Westminster model.<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Goh Chok Tong|mplink=Goh Chok Tong|office=[[Prime Minister of Singapore#List of deputy prime ministers|First Deputy Prime Minister]] and [[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)|Minister for Defence]]|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment No. 2)|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00061822-ZZ|date=29 November 1989|volume=54|column=705}}.</ref> Unlike NCMPs, NMPs are intended to be [[apoliticism|apolitical]] voices in Parliament – the purpose of the NCMP scheme is to have MPs hailing from various fields and professions who can "reflect as wide a range of independent and non-partisan views as possible".<ref>Constitution, Art. 39(1)(c) and the 4th Schedule, para. 3(2).</ref>
Though NMPs may in effect be insignificant as a check on the executive, they can present alternative viewpoints which the Government may consider and even choose to respond to, particularly where they concern socially significant issues. As NMP [[Paulin Tay Straughan]] has said: "The day when we move into a two-party system where opposing voices are more visible, we will not need NMPs or NCMPs anymore. But until we get there, the NMPs have a role to play."<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Paulin Tay Straughan|mplink=Paulin Tay Straughan|office=[[Nominated Member of Parliament]]|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment)|billurl=http://www.parliament.gov.sg/sites/default/files/100003.pdf|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00004346-WA|date=26 April 2010|volume=87|columns=98–99}}.</ref>
===Judicial checks on the legislature and executive=== In ''Law Society of Singapore v. Tan Guat Neo Phyllis'' (2008),<ref>{{cite CommonLII|litigants=Law Society of Singapore v. Tan Guat Neo Phyllis|court=SGHC|year=2007|num=207|parallelcite=[2008] 2 S.L.R.(R.) 239|courtname=H.C.|juris=Singapore}}.</ref> the [[High Court of Singapore|High Court]] described the guardianship role of the judiciary in safeguarding the Constitution and the doctrine of separation of powers, holding that to prevent each arm of government from acting beyond its constitutional powers, "[u]nder the Constitution, the means adopted and recognised by all three arms of government is the judicial power of the court to review the legality of legislative and executive acts and declare them unconstitutional and of no legal effect if they contravene the provisions of the Constitution".<ref>''Tan Guat Neo Phyllis'', p. 310, para. 143.</ref>
====Judicial independence==== {{Main article|Judicial independence in Singapore}}
[[Judicial independence in Singapore|Judicial independence]] from the other branches of government allows the judiciary to act as a check and balance on the exercise of legislative and executive power, and thus enhances the separation of powers. The extent of judicial independence in Singapore can be examined by reference to the way judges are appointed, and, in particular, the independence of the judiciary of the [[State Courts of Singapore|State Courts]]. These two aspects relate specifically to the protection of the judiciary as an institution from extraneous influences, rather than the protection of individual members of the judiciary from external pressures.<ref>{{citation|author=Chan Sek Keong|title=Securing and Maintaining the Independence of the Court in Judicial Proceedings|url=http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/500/%282010%29%2022%20SAcLJ%20229-251%20%28March%29%20Chan%20CJ.pdf|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rrDyGXmI?url=http://www.sal.org.sg/digitallibrary/Lists/SAL%20Journal/Attachments/500/%282010%29%2022%20SAcLJ%20229-251%20%28March%29%20Chan%20CJ.pdf|archivedate=9 August 2010|journal=Singapore Academy of Law Journal|year=2010|volume=22|pages=229–251 at 231 and 235–237|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}.</ref>
=====Supreme Court judiciary===== Appointments of [[judicial officers of the Republic of Singapore#The Chief Justice, Judges of Appeal, and Judges and Judicial Commissioners of the High Court|judges]] and [[Judicial Commissioner]]s (JCs) of the [[Supreme Court of Singapore|Supreme Court]] are made by the President, when, in his discretion, he concurs with the Prime Minister's advice on the matter.<ref>Constitution, Art. 95(1).</ref> The Prime Minister thus possesses the primary power of appointment of judges of the Supreme Court.<ref name="Hor">{{citation|author=Michael Hor|title=The Independence of the Criminal Justice System in Singapore|ssrn=956056|journal=Singapore Journal of Legal Studies|year=2002|pages=497–513 at 501}}.</ref> Although the Prime Minister must consult the [[Chief Justice of Singapore|Chief Justice]] when advising the President to appoint judges and JCs,<ref>Constitution, Art. 95(2).</ref> and the President is empowered to veto judicial appointments,<ref>Constitution, Art. 22(1)(a).</ref> these are relatively small roles played in the final say as to who should be appointed to the judiciary. Thus, it is said that the judiciary may not be an effective check against the abuse of executive power since the executive is likely to appoint judges who believe in the same fundamental policies. This militates against the separation of powers.<ref name="Hor"/> On the other hand, in a small jurisdiction like Singapore, the executive and judicial roles are inevitably intertwined as there will be very few potential appointees to the Supreme Court who have never been involved with the executive government.<ref name="Hor 502">Hor, p. 502.</ref>
The Constitution contains several safeguards to protect the judiciary from political pressures. For instance, Supreme Court judges hold office until the age of 65,<ref>Constitution, Art. 98(1).</ref> and may not be removed from office except under special circumstances. The President may, on the recommendation of a tribunal of five present or former Supreme Court judges from Singapore or judges of equivalent status from any part of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]], remove a judge from office, if the Prime Minister or the Chief Justice acting on the Prime Minister's advice informs him of the judge's misbehaviour or inability to properly discharge the functions of his or her office.<ref>Constitution, Arts. 98(2)–(4).</ref> Supreme Court judges are also constitutionally guaranteed protection from adverse remunerative changes.<ref>Constitution, Art. 98(8); {{citation|author=Li-ann Thio|chapter=Rule of Law within a Non-liberal 'Communitarian' Democracy: The Singapore Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NCXJFFudGd0C&pg=PA188|editor=Randall Peerenboom|title=Asian Discourses of Rule of Law: Theories and Implementation of Rule of Law in Twelve Asian Countries, France and the U.S.|location=London|publisher=[[Routledge]]Curzon|year=2004|pages=183–224 at 188|isbn=978-0-415-32613-1}}.</ref>
It has been argued that the power of the executive to appoint JCs for limited periods or to hear a specific case,<ref>Constitution, Arts. 94(4)–(5).</ref> and to extend the tenure of Supreme Court judges beyond the age of 65 by hiring them on a term basis,<ref>Constitution, Art. 94(3).</ref> may motivate such judges to render decisions that are in line with government policy. As regards the latter, a mechanism for the extension of a judge's tenure might be regarded as necessary to ensure that better judges are not replaced by less capable ones.<ref>Hor, p. 506.</ref>
=====State Courts judiciary===== In Singapore, the lower or subordinate judiciary consists of the District Judges and Magistrates of the State Courts. These judges are members of the [[Singapore Legal Service|Legal Service]], which is governed by the Legal Service Commission ("LSC").<ref>Constitution, Art. 111.</ref> The President appoints State Courts judges from among the members of the Legal Service on the recommendation of the Chief Justice, who is also the chairman of the LSC.<ref>{{Singapore legislation|title=Subordinate Courts Act|cap=321|ed=2007}}, ss. 9–10.</ref>
The LSC is composed of members who enjoy differing degrees of independence from the executive branch.<ref>Hor, p. 505.</ref> These include the Chief Justice, the [[Attorney-General of Singapore|Attorney-General]] and a superior judge appointed by the Chief Justice who are highly independent from executive influence. On the other hand, the remaining persons who are the chairman and two other members of the [[Public Service Commission (Singapore)|Public Service Commission]] enjoy less security of office as they enjoy a tenure of only five years.<ref>Constitution, Art. 107(1).</ref>
The subordinate judiciary in Singapore has come under more scrutiny than the superior judiciary.<ref>Hor, p. 504.</ref> State Courts judges lack tenure, and the LSC determines the terms of their appointments.<ref>Constitution, Art. 111(3).</ref> Thus, the substance of the criticisms is that the career advancement of the lower judiciary depends on the LSC, of which the Attorney-General is a member. Members of the subordinate judiciary can be transferred out of the courts to the Attorney-General's Chambers or to some other government department to serve as legal officers. Thus, there are worries of heavy legislative and executive influence over the appointment and removal of subordinate judges,<ref name="Chan 247">Chan, "Securing and Maintaining the Independence of the Court", p. 247.</ref> and that they will be influenced by government ideology and policy in their role as judges.<ref>Thio, "Rule of Law Within a Non-Liberal 'Communitarian' Democracy", p. 190.</ref>
The case of Senior District Judge Michael Khoo being appointed as a deputy public prosecutor in August 1981 is often cited in this context. The appointment occurred shortly after Khoo had acquitted [[J. B. Jeyaretnam]], a prominent opposition MP, of certain charges of having fraudulently transferred cheques to prevent the distribution of money to the creditors of the [[Workers' Party of Singapore]], and of making a false declaration. The reason for the transfer was never conclusively established; while it could have been motivated by executive disapproval of the acquittals, it may well have been a routine transfer with no implications for executive interference in the subordinate judiciary. The latter was the official explanation for the transfer.<ref>{{citation|title=Report of the Commission of Inquiry into Allegations of Executive Interference in the Subordinate Courts [Cmd. 12 of 1986; Chairman: [[T. S. Sinnathuray]]]|location=Singapore|publisher=Printed for the [[Government of Singapore]] by the Singapore National Printers|year=1986|oclc=16872490}}.</ref>
However, it has also been said that observations about the apparent connections between the executive and judiciary are merely theoretical, and that for a more accurate analysis of the separation of powers in Singapore the "[j]udiciary must be judged on its performance in the context of actual litigation".<ref name="Hor 502"/> Furthermore, assertions that the subordinate judiciary is not separate from the executive since the LSC is allied to the government disregard the fact that the Chief Justice is the head of the LSC and has the final say on judicial postings. Moreover, in a small state, it may not be feasible to have a separate judicial and legal service.<ref name="Chan 247"/>
====Judicial review==== In ''Mohammad Faizal bin Sabtu v. Public Prosecutor'' (2012),<ref name="Mohammad Faizal"/> the High Court explained that the doctrine of separation of powers "entails, in so far as the judicial branch is concerned, that the legislative and the executive branches of the State may not interfere with the exercise of the judicial power by the judicial branch. This total separation between the exercise of the judicial power on the one hand and the exercise of the legislative and the executive powers on the other hand is based on the rule of law."<ref>''Mohammad Faizal'', p. 960, para. 19.</ref>
In Singapore, the Supreme Court upholds the separation of powers and constitutional supremacy by exercising jurisdiction to judicially review the constitutionality of legislation, thereby acting as a check upon the legislature. The High Court in ''[[Chan Hiang Leng Colin v. Public Prosecutor]]'' (1994)<ref>{{cite WorldLII|litigants=Chan Hiang Leng Colin v. Public Prosecutor|link=Chan Hiang Leng Colin v. Public Prosecutor|court=ICHRL|year=1994|num=26|parallelcite=[https://www.webcitation.org/6Bhm2ZjV3?url=http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1994%5D_SGHC_207.html [1994] SGHC 207], [1994] 3 S.L.R.(R.) [''Singapore Law Reports (Reissue)''] 209, archived from [http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1994%5D_SGHC_207.html the original] on 26 October 2012|courtname=H.C.|juris=Singapore}}.</ref> held that the court has "the power and duty to ensure that the provisions of the Constitution are observed. The court also has a duty to declare invalid any exercise of power, legislative and executive, which exceeds the limits of the power conferred by the Constitution, or which contravenes any prohibition which the Constitution provides."<ref>''Chan Hiang Leng Colin'', p. 231, para. 50.</ref> The Supreme Court also exercises supervisory jurisdiction over inferior tribunals and public authorities, and can hold that acts and decisions by them which infringe [[administrative law in Singapore|administrative law rules]] are invalid.<ref>{{cite CommonLII|litigants=Ng Chye Huey v. Public Prosecutor|court=SGCA|year=2007|num=3|parallelcite=[2007] 2 S.L.R.(R.) 106|courtname=auto}}.</ref>
====Limits of judicial review====
=====Constitutional and legislative prohibitions===== While the judiciary is empowered to declare ordinary legislation unconstitutional, the legislature is able to overrule such decisions by amending the Constitution. For example, in ''[[Chng Suan Tze v. Minister for Home Affairs]]'' (1988),<ref>''Chng Suan Tze v. Minister for Home Affairs'' [https://www.webcitation.org/64ATf2EyI?url=http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1988%5D_SGCA_16.html [1988] SGCA 16], [1988] 2 S.L.R.(R.) 525, C.A. (Singapore), archived from [http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1988%5D_SGCA_16.html the original] on 24 December 2011.</ref> the [[Court of Appeal of Singapore|Court of Appeal]] adopted an objective test for reviewing ministerial discretion in the issuance of preventive detention orders under the [[Internal Security Act (Singapore)|Internal Security Act]] ("ISA").<ref>{{Singapore legislation|title=Internal Security Act|titlelink=Internal Security Act (Singapore)|cap=143|ed=1985}}.</ref> However, within a month of the decision, Parliament amended the Constitution and the Internal Security Act<ref>By the {{Singapore legislation|title=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Act|url=http://statutes.agc.gov.sg/aol/search/display/view.w3p;ident=7a97e1b8-2bcb-44b1-9efa-3fa39974a056;page=0;query=DocId%3Af34d7a09-f1c1-40a9-aef1-43f20af67613%20Depth%3A0%20ValidTime%3A{{CURRENTDAY2}}%2F{{CURRENTMONTH}}%2F{{CURRENTYEAR}}%20TransactionTime%3A{{CURRENTDAY2}}%2F{{CURRENTMONTH}}%2F{{CURRENTYEAR}}%20Status%3Ainforce;rec=0|no=1|year=1989}} and the {{Singapore legislation|title=Internal Security (Amendment) Act|url=http://statutes.agc.gov.sg/aol/search/display/view.w3p;ident=d12017f8-0f05-4ebc-abee-28abe10c2048;page=0;query=DocId%3Adff584d2-1d5d-4d9d-8aac-2f8d16dabdd3%20Depth%3A0%20ValidTime%3A{{CURRENTDAY2}}%2F{{CURRENTMONTH}}%2F{{CURRENTYEAR}}%20TransactionTime%3A{{CURRENTDAY2}}%2F{{CURRENTMONTH}}%2F{{CURRENTYEAR}}%20Status%3Ainforce;rec=0|no=2|year=1989}}. See {{Singapore Hansard|title=Third Reading of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Bill|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00061339-ZZ|date=25 January 1989|volume=52|column=530}}; {{Singapore Hansard|title=Third Reading of the Internal Security Act (Amendment) Bill|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00061342-ZZ|date=25 January 1989|volume=52|column=556}}.</ref> to reinstate the subjective test espoused in ''Lee Mau Seng v. Minister for Home Affairs'' (1971).<ref>''Lee Mau Seng v. Minister for Home Affairs'' [https://www.webcitation.org/64T7GPsjN?url=http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1971%5D_SGHC_10.html [1971] SGHC 10], [1971–1973] S.L.R.(R.) 135, H.C. (Singapore), archived from [http://lwb.lawnet.com.sg/legal/lgl/rss/landmark/%5B1971%5D_SGHC_10.html the original] on 5 January 2012.</ref>
This form of legislative over-ruling, if done frequently, has two major detrimental effects. First, if the legislature or executive is seen as being able to manipulate the constitutional limits on their powers, this greatly impairs judicial independence. Secondly, it may thwart the perception that the judiciary is a co-equal institution in the scheme of the separation of powers, thus causing a loss of respect and public confidence in the system.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Judiciary|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=451–567 at 537|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref> Speaking in Parliament during the [[reading (legislature)#Second reading|Second Reading]] of the bill amending the Constitution to reverse the effect of ''Chng Suan Tze'', the [[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Minister for Law]] [[S. Jayakumar]] quoted [[Kenneth Diplock, Baron Diplock|Lord Diplock]] to justify this truncation of judicial review on the basis that national security is "the responsibility of the executive government", and it is a [[threshold issues in Singapore administrative law#Justiciability|non-justiciable]] question which "the judicial process is totally inept to deal with".<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants=Council of Civil Service Unions v. Minister for the Civil Service|link=Council of Civil Service Unions v Minister for the Civil Service|court=UKHL|year=1983|num=6|parallelcite=[1985] A.C. 374 at 412|courtname=auto}}.</ref> He stated that the executive would be accountable to both Parliament and the people for its exercise of discretionary powers.<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=S. Jayakumar|mplink=S. Jayakumar|office=[[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Minister for Law]]|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment)|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00061339-ZZ|date=25 January 1989|volume=52|column=466}}.</ref>
Further, the political branches of government may seek to limit judicial review through the use of [[exclusion of judicial review in Singapore law#Total ouster or finality clauses|ouster clauses]]. Examples of such clauses include Article 18(9) of the Constitution, section 8B(2) of the ISA, and section 18 of the [[Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act]].<ref>{{Singapore legislation|title=Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act|titlelink=Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act|cap=167A|ed=2001}}.</ref> However, it remains an open question whether ouster clauses are fully effective or whether, as the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]] held in ''[[Anisminic v Foreign Compensation Commission|Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission]]'' (1968),<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants=Anisminic Ltd. v. Foreign Compensation Commission|link=Anisminic v Foreign Compensation Commission|court=UKHL|year=1968|num=6|parallelcite=[1969] 2 A.C. 147|courtname=auto}}.</ref> they do not apply to the acts and decisions of public authorities that are a nullity.<ref>''Anisminic'', p. 170.</ref> Speaking extrajudicially, Chief Justice [[Chan Sek Keong]] suggested that any statutory clause attempting to oust the supervisory jurisdiction of the courts may contravene Article 93, which vests the judicial power of Singapore in the courts.<ref>Chan, "Judicial Review – From Angst to Empathy", p. 477, para. 19.</ref>
=====Doctrine of non-justiciability===== The courts have developed an internal doctrine of self-imposed [[judicial restraint]] by which they will either decline to review what they consider a non-justiciable issue, calibrate review to a low intensity, or exercise review on limited grounds.<ref>Thio, "The Judiciary", pp. 538–539, para. 10.219.</ref>
In matters pertaining to "high policy" such as [[jus tractatuum|treaty-making]], national defence and [[foreign relations]], the courts will generally decline judicial review of the exercise of power in deference to the executive.<ref>Thio, "Constitutional Principles", pp. 162–163, para. 03.024.</ref> This doctrine stems from the idea that there are cases dealing with subject matters which fall beyond the purview of judicial review.<ref>Thio, "The Judiciary", p. 539, para. 10.221.</ref> The court's decision to intervene or not is guided by the following four principles enunciated by Judicial Commissioner [[Sundaresh Menon]] in ''Lee Hsien Loong v. Review Publishing Co Ltd'' (2007):<ref>{{cite CommonLII|litigants=Lee Hsien Loong v. Review Publishing Co. Ltd.|court=SGHC|year=2007|num=24|parallelcite=[2007] 2 S.L.R.(R.) 453 at 490, para. 98|courtname=H.C.|juris=Singapore}}.</ref>
*Justiciability depends not on the source of the decision-making power, but on the subject-matter that is in question. Where it is the executive that has access to the best materials available to resolve the issue, its views should be regarded as highly persuasive, if not decisive. *Where the decision involves matters of government policy and requires the intricate balancing of various competing policy considerations that judges are ill-equipped to adjudicate because of their limited training, experience and access to materials, the courts should shy away from reviewing its merits. *Where a judicial pronouncement could embarrass some other branch of government or tie its hands in the conduct of affairs traditionally regarded as falling within its purview, the courts should abstain from acting. *In all cases of judicial review, the court should exercise restraint and take cognisance of the fact that the Singapore system of government operates within the framework of three co-equal branches. Even though all exercise of power must be within constitutional and legal bounds, there are areas of prerogative power that the democratically elected executive and legislature are entrusted to take charge of, and, in this regard, it is to the electorate, and not the judiciary, that the executive and legislature are ultimately accountable.
However, areas of high policy such as national security do not automatically apply as a "[[peremptory plea|plea in bar]]".<ref>''Chng Suan Tze'', p. 557, para. 94.</ref> On scrutiny of such cases which are ''prima facie'' non-justiciable, the courts may be able to glean a question of law that is justiciable.<ref>''Lee Hsien Loong'', p. 490, para. 98.</ref>
=====Prosecutorial discretion===== While Article 93 of the Constitution vests judicial power in the courts, Article 35(8) provides that "[t]he Attorney-General shall have power, exercisable at his discretion, to institute, conduct or discontinue any proceedings for any offence". In ''Tan Guat Neo Phyllis'', the High Court stated that these two provisions expressly separate the prosecutorial function from the judicial function, and that they are coequal. As such, the two functions are not to encroach upon each other, although the court may interfere where prosecutorial power has been exercised in [[bad faith]] or unconstitutionally.<ref>''Tan Guat Neo Phyllis'', p. 311, para. 144.</ref>
==Intra-branch checks==
===Elected President as a check on the Government=== [[File:Tony Tan 20110623.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Tony Tan|Tony Tan Keng Yam]], who was [[President of Singapore]] from 2011 to 2017]]
The office of the Elected President of Singapore represents an indigenisation of the Westminster system of government and is cast as a check against the powers enjoyed by the parliamentary executive, adding to the overall scheme of checks and balances in the doctrine of separation of powers.<ref>Thio, "Constitutional Principles", p. 161, paras. 03.021–03.022.</ref> Nonetheless, the institution has a limited range of functions and is essentially reactive in nature, such that it cannot be seen to be an alternative locus of political power.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The President|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=385–450 at 435, para. 09.116|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref> The President has power to block attempts by the Government to draw down past reserves it did not accumulate, to approve changes to key appointments, and to exercise oversight over the [[Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau]] and decisions of the executive under the ISA and the MRHA.<ref name="Art 21(2)">Constitution, Art. 21(2).</ref> The aim is not to enable the President to target unlawful executive actions, but lawful actions against national interests.<ref>Thio, "The President", p. 395, para. 09.022.</ref>
The impetus behind the introduction of the scheme was the Government's perception that there were "inadequate checks in our present parliamentary system of government" as a political party with a parliamentary majority, even of one seat, "can do practically anything it wishes, provided it acts lawfully" in matters pertaining to financial assets and key appointments. It was also thought that it would be prudent to institute a check "while honest men are still in charge".<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Goh Chok Tong|office=First Deputy Prime Minister|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment No. 3)|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00062193-ZZ|date=4 October 1999|volume=56|columns=461–462}}.</ref> While the objective of protecting against fiscal mismanagement was agreed on, the method of doing so was disputed, with opposition politicians arguing that the parliamentary system would have sufficient checks if opposition parties were allowed to operate more freely and to flourish.<ref>{{Singapore Hansard|mp=Lee Siew-Choh|mplink=Lee Siew-Choh|office=[[Non-constituency Member of Parliament|NCMP]]|reading=Second|bill=Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment No. 3)|url=http://sprs.parl.gov.sg/search/topic.jsp?currentTopicID=00062193-ZZ|date=4 October 1999|volume=56|column=491}}.</ref>
====Presidential independence====
To be an effective check, the President must be sufficiently independent and adequately empowered to change or at least block harmful or unsound government policies.<ref>Thio, "The President", p. 412, para. 09.061.</ref> Various constitutional provisions seek to achieve this. The President cannot hold any other constitutional office; if a person was an MP prior to being elected as President, the parliamentary seat is to be vacated.<ref>Constitution, Arts. 19(3)(a) and (d).</ref> To stand as a candidate in a [[presidential elections in Singapore|presidential election]], a candidate is also required to resign his or her membership in any [[list of political parties in Singapore|political party]], reflecting the depoliticisation of the elective office.<ref>Constitution, Art. 19(2)(f). The President is also prohibited from reacquiring membership in a political party following his or her election: Art. 19(3)(c). The requirements to vacate a parliamentary seat and to resign from membership of a political party do not apply to someone temporarily exercising the powers of the President: Art. 19(4).</ref> To ensure that the President's watchdog function is unhampered by executive intimidation, the office is maintained out of the [[President of Singapore#Maintenance: The Civil List|Civil List]] which cannot be diminished during the President's term.<ref>Constitution, Art. 22J.</ref> The President is also immune from civil suits for acts done in his official capacity.<ref>Constitution, Art. 22K.</ref>
====Discretionary powers of the President====
{{main article|Powers of the President of Singapore}}
The President has [[powers of the President of Singapore|discretionary power]] to veto certain executive decisions pertaining primarily to three areas: fiscal management, ensuring meritocracy in a corruption-free [[Singapore Civil Service|civil service]], and guardianship over [[civil liberties]] where [[judicial review in Singapore|judicial review]] has been ousted.<ref name="Art 21(2)"/> For the purpose of carrying out his functions, the President is entitled to access to Cabinet papers and may request information concerning the reserves of the Government, or of any [[Government of Singapore#Statutory boards|statutory board]] or government company listed in the Fifth Schedule to the Constitution. The relevant minister, or officer of the statutory board or government company, is under a duty to provide such information.<ref>Constitution, Art. 22F.</ref>
The President, however, does not have the final say over certain decisions, as Parliament may override his veto with a resolution supported by not less than two-thirds of all the elected MPs. For instance, this mechanism applies if the President vetoes key civil service appointments<ref>Constitution, Art. 22(2).</ref> or withholds assent to bills that are likely to draw on the nation's past reserves.<ref>Constitution, Art. 148D.</ref> A prerequisite for the exercise of the override mechanism is that the President must have disagreed with the recommendation of the Council of Presidential Advisers, which he is required consult before exercising these powers.<ref>For example, this is stated in the Constitution, Arts. 22(2) and 148D.</ref> The override mechanism shows that the President's discretionary powers pose no obstacle to a government which continues to enjoy untrammelled power so long as it controls a clear two-thirds parliamentary majority. The weaker the Government is, the stronger the presidential check is; and the stronger the Government, the weaker the presidential blocking mechanism.<ref>Thio, "The President", p. 415, para. 09.069.</ref>
===Presidential Council of Minority Rights as a check on the legislature=== Singapore has a unicameral legislature, meaning that there is no division of legislative authority between an [[upper house|upper]] and a [[lower house]]. Nevertheless, the [[Presidential Council for Minority Rights]] ("PCMR") can be seen as a quasi-second chamber as it plays a role in legislative review, highlighting bills containing measures that discriminate against racial and religious minorities. Thus, it plays a role in the separation of powers by acting as a check upon the executive and legislature.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann|chapter=The Presidential Council for Minority Rights|title=A Treatise on Singapore Constitutional Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Academy Publishing|year=2012|pages=361–367 at 361|isbn=978-981-07-1516-8}}.</ref>
However, Parliament can easily circumvent an adverse report on a bill by the PCMR as it can continue to present the bill to the President for assent if not less than two-thirds of all the elected MPs endorse a [[motion (parliamentary procedure)|motion]] in favour of such action.<ref>Constitution, Art. 78(6)(c).</ref> The PCMR's powers of legislative review are further attenuated because the Constitution designates certain types of bills as falling outside the ambit of its scrutiny, namely, [[money bill]]s, bills certified by the Prime Minister as affecting "the defence or the security of Singapore" or relating to "public safety, peace or good order in Singapore", and urgent bills.<ref>Constitution, Art. 78(7).</ref> Thus the PCMR has been said to be a weak institution that lacks coercive power.<ref>Thio, "The Presidential Council for Minority Rights", p. 366, para. 07.017.</ref>
